DO NOT APPLY DIRECTLY TO BUYER All submissions will be assessed in accordance with the Public Contracts Regulations 2015, for procurement values that exceed Regulation 5 (Threshold amounts) Responses must be received by the date in the tender documentation; responses received outside of the deadline or not sent via the eSourcing portal will not be accepted or considered further for this opportunity. How to Register on the CCS eSourcing Suite If you have not yet registered on the eSourcing Suite, this can be done online at https://gpsesourcing.cabinetoffice.gov.uk by following the link 'Register for CCS eSourcing'. Please note that, to register, you must have a valid DUNS number (as provided by Dun and Bradstreet) for the organisation which you are registering, who will be entering into a contract if invited to do so. Once you have registered on the eSourcing Suite, a registered user can express an interest for a specific procurement. This is done by emailing expressionofinterest@crowncommercial.gov.uk. Your email must clearly state: • name and reference for the procurement you wish to register for; • name of the registered Bidder; • name and contact details for the registered individual sending the email. Crown Commercial Service will process the email and then enable the Bidder to access the procurement online via the e-Sourcing Suite. The registered user will receive a notification email to alert them once this has been done. The Sourcing documents can then be accessed on the eSourcing Suite at: https://gpsesourcing.cabinetoffice.gov.uk using the instructions
detailed in the Specification documents within Contracts Finder. As a user of the e-Sourcing Suite you will have access to Emptoris email messaging service which facilitates all messages sent to you and from you in relation to any specific RFX event. Please note it is your responsibility to access these emails on a regular basis to ensure you have sight of all relevant information. For technical assistance on use of the e-Sourcing Suite please contact Crown Commercial Service Helpdesk: Telephone: 0345 010 3503 Training documents to support Bidders to utilise Emptoris CCS eSourcing are available in the Contracts Finder Tender documents section. Title: Specialist Live Events - Event Management Services
Description:
DIT produces, delivers and manages multiple events/presence at events per year on behalf of the UK. This contract focuses on the planning, delivery and management of events classified as Major Live World Events and Specialist Ministerial Events. Together these are Specialist Live Events and form the most important and high profile events the Department is involved in. The Ministerial events include events commissioned by No.10 for the Prime Minister, Chancellor or the DIT SoS. Major Live World Events will include the delivery of the UK Presence at Expos, or at international events such as the Olympics, Commonwealth Games or World Cups.

DIT has run a competitive tender process under the Crown Commercial Services (CCS) Framework for Communication Services (RM3796), Lot 2 - Events, awarding the contract to the Most Economically Advantageous Tender (MEAT).

Title: Financial Services
Description:
1.2	The PDP is required to deliver FS focused Technical Assistance (TA) activities through three Components, including: 
a) Programme Management Unit (PMU) managing a combination of multiple rounds of competitive tenders and call for bids to disburse funds to third-party organisations and experts, and a Strategic Engagement Facility to support UK Government engagement in China; 
b) ad-hoc scoping and advisory services provided to the Authority; and 
c) a capped allocation of TA activities for the PDP to implement.

1.3	The Programme will operate between May 2019 and March 2022. The £16.5m Programme budget is comprised of a total contract value for the PDP in the range of £3.3m-£5.775m (inclusive of VAT  and all applicable government taxes) and the remaining Programme budget, which is to be disbursed by the PDP via the PMU Component. 
1.4	The Programme Portfolio includes a discrete workstream of activities within the Financial Inclusion Pillar focused on agricultural (micro-)insurance products, up to £3m, to be procured and managed separately to this tender, though this is subject to an ongoing planning process and may be liable to change (that could only result in an uplift to this tender value). The Programme as set out in this tender will require TA activities in all five Pillars, including Financial Inclusion.

Title: Operational Ration Heater Systems (ORHS)
Description:
The requirement is for an Operational Ration Heater System (ORHS) which consists of portable metal stoveand solid fuel blocks to enable an individual to boil water and heat military field rations in a range of weatherconditions. The solid fuel must be Ethanol based (Bio-Fuel) any other fuels such as Hexamine will not beaccepted.
1: Heating Performance - The ORHS must be capable of boiling 500ml water to a temperature of 100C instandard issue MOD equipment (mess tins) within 11 minutes at an air temperature of -8C to +40C and sustainthe temperature for a period of 5 minutes.
2: Tactical Performance - The ORHS must function within 10 minutes of being immersed in water, this is to allowindividuals to prepare a meal after wading through water.
3: Tactical Performance - The ORHS must be as small and light as possible. The total weight (Stove & Fuel)must be max. 330g with sufficient fuel to heat a total of 6 meals or hot drinks.
4: Tactical Performance - The ORHS fuel must be tactically viable - smoke, noise, smell and light must be keptto a minimum.
5: Tactical Performance - The ORHS must be able to operate in poor climatic conditions and operate in wet andwindy weather.
6: Compatibility - The ORHS must be compatible with VIRTUS and OSPREY utility pouch and must be carriedin a utility pouch (16.5cm x 10cm x 7.5cm) and still b able to heat a minimum of 6 meals or hot drinks in a 24Hrperiod
7: Safety - The ORHS must be able to be safely transported in bulk by rail, air, road or sea.

Title: 144_19 Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) & Clothing
Description:
An ESPO national Framework for the supply of Personal Protective Equipment and various clothing (including but not limited to wear for corporate, health & social care, school, leisure, catering and emergency services).The framework agreement will be open for use by those users deemed permissible and will operate on the basis of direct award and further competition. 

Lot 1: PPE (Personal Protective Equipment) and Clothing

Lot 2: Corporate Workwear - Includes but is not limited to: t-shirts, polo shirts, sweatshirts, shirts, trousers, blazers, leggings, fleeces, ties, caps, hats, jackets and safety and non-safety footwear.

Lot 3 - Health and Social Care Workwear - Includes but is not limited to, full length dresses, maternity dresses, tunics, maternity tunics, shirts, trousers, scrub tops and trousers and patient pyjama tops and trousers.

Lot 4: Schoolwear - Includes but is not limited to: t-shirts, polo shirts, sweatshirts, cardigans, fleeces, body warmer, blouses, blazers, shirts, ties, skirts, trousers, shorts, hoodies, laboratory coats, aprons and non-safety shoes.

Lot 5: Leisurewear - Includes but is not limited to, t-shirts, polo shirts, jogging bottoms, tracksuits, shorts, jackets, fleeces, trainers and sports bibs.

Lot 6: Catering Wear - Includes but is not limited to: mesh hats, hair nets, food processing aprons, tabards, disposable clothing, gloves and chef's jackets and trousers.

Lot 7: Emergency Services Workwear - Includes but is not limited to: shirts, t-shirts, polo shirts, tunics, trousers, skirts, jackets, fleeces, joggers, shorts, coveralls, helmets, trainers and safety shoes.

The framework agreement has the option to extend for up to a further 24 months. The total estimated value stated includes the option period.

An eAuction process may be used to award subsequent call off contracts following the reopening of competition among the parties to the Framework Agreement.

To tender: (a) Go to www.eastmidstenders.org, (b) Register (c) Search for tender opportunity '144_19' d) Express an interest (e) Download the tender from the website.

Please note:  the closing date for submission of tenders is 12:00 midday, 08/07/2019
Additional Text:
As a Central Purchasing Body as defined by the EU Procurement Directive 2014/24/EU, the Framework Agreement is open for use by Public Bodies (defined at https://www.espo.org/ESPO/media/Documents/FAQs/ESPO-s_powers_to_trade__website_-2016-12-22.pdf) that also fall into one of the following classifications of user throughout all administrative regions of the UK: Local Authorities; Educational Establishments (including Academies); Central Government Departments and Agencies; Police, Fire & Rescue and Coastguard Emergency Services; NHS and HSC Bodies, including Ambulance Services; Registered Charities; Registered Social Landlords; The Corporate Office of the House of Lords, The Corporate Officer of the House of Commons; or any public body established by or under the Scotland Act 1998 or any Act of the Scottish Parliament. Details of the classification of end user establishments and geographical areas are available at: http://www.espo.org/About-us-%281%29/FAQs/Legal

The following information is applicable to all lots: ESPO has established a commercial trading company, ESPO Trading Limited, whose target clients are third sector organisations such as national and local charities, public sector mutual organisations and other organisations involved in the delivery of services to or for the public sector. The successful Supplier may be asked to enter into an additional separate framework agreement (the Second Framework) with ESPO Trading Limited on materially similar terms to that found in the tender pack to be entered into by ESPO itself. Any Second Framework agreement will be a purely commercial agreement and will, for the avoidance of doubt, not be governed by the Public Contract Regulations 2015 or other public procurement legislation. ESPO Trading Limited may enter into the second framework agreement with the successful supplier and make it available to third sector clients who themselves are not required to follow the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 or other public procurement legislation. Accordingly, this is provided forbidders' information only.

Organisation Name: NHS Arden and Greater East Midlands Commissioning Support Unit
Title: NHS East Kent CCGs Local Care Mental Health Services
Description:
The Service(s) will be required to meet the following needs:
Aims and objectives of service
•	Embed a Mental Health in Local Care service in East Kent 
•	Offer the Mental Health in Local Care service in a way that is compatible with other local care services within the enhanced primary care networks model
•	Offer the Mental Health in Local Care services using a range of technology and delivery formats to facilitate the maximum uptake of services
•	Reduce the level of mental health illness for those individuals entering Mental Health in Local Care services 
•	Improve the service user for those individuals entering Mental Health in Local Care services 
•	Reduce the number of encounters with other primary, secondary and emergency services for the supported patient group

Objectives
•	Work with GPs in primary care by providing treatment and support for those patients who the GP identifies would benefit from additional mental health support
•	Provide referral/signposting to other services as deemed appropriate
•	Provide advice; guidance and training to primary care providers
•	Provide a range of NICE approved interventions that are based on clinical need
•	Support the provision of Depot Antipsychotics in Local Care
•	Support the discharge from specialist Mental Health services to Mental Health in Local Care services where it is agreed the person is stable and well enough to be discharged however still needs short term support 
•	Proactive support the Multi-Disciplinary Team working within the Enhanced Primary Care Network model 
•	Proactively build positive working relationships with appropriate partners to ensure effective service delivery and seamless patient experience

Title: Queen Elizabeth's Girls' School - Tender for Cleaning Services
Description:
Queen Elizabeth's Girls' School in Barnet is an 11-18 fully comprehensive state school with approximately 1 200 students and 150 staff. We are proud to consistently be over-subscribed and a school of choice within the local community, with a strong reputation for educating women of the future. Our consistently high examination results place us in the top 1 % of all schools nationally, which is an incredible achievement for a fully comprehensive state school. We continue to build on our strong results year-on-year and we are an emerging centre of excellence for a number of areas of our practice, having gained SSAT and DFE recognition in recent months.

The successful supplier will be required to provide cleaning services at Queen Elizabeth's Girls' School.

Tender information:

The tender project is seeking to appoint a Supplier whose initiative and innovation will be welcomed for the provision of cleaning services within the school's facilities. The high quality service levels proposed, should maintain excellent standards throughout, resulting in a pleasant environment for both the pupils and staff.

The basis and rationale that the client requires the successful supplier to operate to at all times, is being able to provide a school that is fit for purpose and that the supplier is proactive in the management of the contract, thus ensuring that all specifications are achieved and that the frequency of cleans is as detailed within the tender specification.

The contract being tendered is for three years in duration from 1.8.2019 until 31.7.2022 with the option to extend upon agreement with the client for a further 2-year period. The contract will be fixed price in nature, with the Supplier invoicing the client for one-twelfth of the annual cost on a monthly basis.

It should be noted that the successful Supplier will be expected to bring to the contract: innovation; new equipment; and cleaning methods with BICSc standards being achieved, as a minimum, thus ensuring that the highest levels of cleanliness are maintained in all areas at all times and also ensuring that the productivity of the cleaning operatives is enhanced moving forward into the new contract term. Efficient and effective supervision and management of this contract is paramount.

Current cleaning arrangements:

At present the following staffing structure is in place:

- 1 x non-working cleaning supervisor a.m. and p.m. shift 6 hours per day ~ 47.2 weeks + annual leave = 52 weeks per annum,

- 1 x Team Leader 2 hours per day p.m. (term time and periodics),

- 19 cleaning operatives 9 x a.m. 10 x p.m. (term time and periodics),

- 1 x Day Janitor 4 hrs 10:00 a.m-2:00 p.m (term time only),

- 1 x Day Janitor 6 hrs 11:30 a.m-5:30 p.m. (term time only).

The current contractor is Birkin Cleaning Services.

No incumbent members of cleaning staff are members of the LGPS.

Further information is provided in the SQ Documentation.
Additional Text:
Interest in the selection process should be expressed via email only to pqq@litmuspartnership.co.uk clearly stating within this email which contract / notice you are referring to. Please also provide, as a minimum, a contact name, full company postal address and telephone number.

The Selection Questionnaire and associated documents can be obtained at: http://www.litmuspartnership.co.uk/project/queen_elizabeths_girls_school

The closing date for receipt of the Selection Questionnaire is 15.2.2019 (12:00). Suppliers are required to ensure that documents are obtained and returned to The Litmus Partnership Limited, by email to pqq@litmuspartnership.co.uk by the above closing date and time.

Documents in respect of economic / financial standing (where indicated in the Selection Questionnaire) shall be returned to The Litmus Partnership Limited, by email to pqq@litmuspartnership.co.uk by the above closing date and time.

It will be the Supplier's responsibility to obtain any necessary documents in order to submit a response by the closing date and time.

The contracting authority reserves the right not to award any or part of the contract which is the subject of this Contract Notice and reserves the right to terminate the procurement process at any time.

The contracting authority will not be liable for any costs incurred by those expressing an interest in tendering for this contract opportunity.

The contracting authority will consider variant bids, evaluating them (so far as the variant or the evaluation of the variant is in the opinion of the contracting authority practicable) on the same basis as a conforming bid, but shall not be obliged to accept any such bid in preference to a conforming bid even if the variant bid scores more highly. No variant will be considered unless the bidder simultaneously submits a conforming bid.

Title: Targeted Assurance Review
Description:
The ORR are seeking support from a suitably informed consultant who has a demonstrable knowledge of UK rail infrastructure standards and procedures regarding management and structural assessment of structures. 
The requirements for the assessment of structures on the railway were given in NR/SP/CIV/035: Assessment of Structures (NR, 2004). Network Rail's standard adopted a two stage assessment process comprising of Level 1 and Level 2 assessment. Level 1, the simplest level, and Level 2 typically including advanced methods of structural analysis.  
In 2011 Network Rail developed an assessment technique to support the rapid delivery of an Assessment Programme which covered 13,431 bridge assessments across the network. The new assessment technique is described as a Level 0 assessment. 
The Level 0 assessment is a simplified assessment based on principal checks of critical sections and conservative load distribution. First time assessment of structures using a Level 0 approach is generally based on recorded information and supplementary site investigations as determined by the Asset Engineer.
We require the successful consultant to review the use of the Level 0 tool, assessment processes and its impact in the asset's long term management as set out in 2.2.

Title: Framework Agreement for Minor Highway Works (Basingstoke and Deane Borough Council and Test Valley Borough Council)
Description:
Basingstoke and Deane Borough Council in partnership with Test Valley Borough Council are seeking expressions of interest from relevant suppliers to tender for their Framework Contract for Minor Highway Works. Please note that this Framework contract covers the Borough of Basingstoke and Deane and the Borough of Test Valley, both in Hampshire.

The contract will operate for a period of 3 years with a 1 year option to extend, and is expected to commence from 01/09/2019 and cover Highway Civil Engineering projects ranging anywhere from a few hundred pounds up to £75,000.00.

Typical works let through this contract are of a Highway Civil Engineering nature and range from the construction of drop kerbs and small footway links to the implementation of additional parking projects and neighbourhood regeneration schemes.  Any one project could comprise elements of traffic management, site clearance, fencing, drainage, earthworks, kerbing, macadam surfacing and / or street furniture installation; hence suitable bidders will be those with experience of all of these areas.

This Framework contract comprises submitted rates against each individual item listed within the Contract Schedule of Items. Bidders must be able to supply every item listed within Document 5 Appendix 1 Schedule of Works.
Any contractor wishing to be considered for appointment onto this framework agreement must complete and return the PAS 91 prequalification questionnaire. Responses to the prequalification questionnaire will be used to draw up a restricted list of companies invited to participate further in the procurement process. The number of companies to be invited to tender as a result of this opportunity notice will be restricted to a minimum of 5 and maximum of 7 suppliers (this will only be exceeded where multiple suppliers have the same total score) with a total of up to 5 suppliers appointed to the framework contract.
The Council is utilising an electronic tendering tool to manage this procurement and communicate with suppliers.  Accordingly, there will be no hard copy documents issued to bidders and all communications with the Council, including the submission of Supplier Responses, will be conducted via the ProContract system, which can be accessed using the following link:	
http://sebp.due-north.com

For the information of Tenderers, advice on accessing the system is available using the following link: https://supplierhelp.due-north.com   
If you need further assistance using the ProContract system please contact the PROACTIS support team or Email ProContractSuppliers@proactis.com OR log a support call directly using the following link: http://proactis.kayako.com/procontractv3/Core/Default/Index

Title: P5514 BARNSLEY STREET DHS DIVERSIONS
Description:
Portal Contract Reference: DN416310
Internal Contract Reference: P5514
Contract Title: Barnsley Street District Heating Diversions
Expressions of interest start date: 17/06/2019
Return of tenders/bids end date: 16 July 2019
Initial Contract Duration: 28 Weeks
Extensions: 0
Estimated Contract Value (including extensions): £800,000
Description: A new development of 53 flats in 3 blocks will be built on Collingwood Estate in 2019/2020. The new development requires some of the existing district heating services to be modified and re-routed to the existing plantrooms.
Works will consist of works to the existing culvert, working in confined spaces, stripping out of old services, digging new trenches for new mains pipework, works to the plantrooms and hard & soft landscaping works.
The project is located within the Collingwood Estate residential housing estate situated within the road/street boundaries of Barnsley Street to the north, Collingwood Street to the west, Darling Row to the south and Cambridge Heath Road (A107) to the east. Headlam Street bisects the estate running east/west.
There will be works within the plant rooms of existing residential buildings and these buildings will be occupied whilst the works are being carried out.

Additional Information:

The London Borough of Tower Hamlets (LBTH) is seeking expressions of interest from interested organisations for the above services and / or goods.

Organisations wishing to express their interest are requested to register on the London Tenders Portal (www.londontenders.org) where the opportunity documentation will be available for download. You will be required to complete an online questionnaire.
Organisations must ensure that access to the system is available to their representatives dealing with the contract and that this contact is updated as and when required. 
The council will not be liable for the lack of delegated access within the organisation and will not send any documentation regarding the opportunity, which shall be exclusively available through the portal.

Suppliers are responsible for allowing sufficient time to submit their Application. The Council accepts no liability whatsoever for tenders that are not submitted due to internet connectivity issues, transmission delays or errors. 

Council is an Equal Opportunities Employer and a supporter of Ethical Governance, our protocol can be found HERE Or via http://www.towerhamlets.gov.uk/ 
If you require any further information prior to submit and expression of interest please contact the Council via email procurement@towerhamlets.gov.uk quoting the contract internal reference number.

Title: Productive General Practice Quick Start (PGP QS)
Description: OJEU tender for replacement contracts for the Time for Care programme - Productive General Practice Quick Start programme.
Additional Text:
Delivery Partners (DP's) were sought to deliver the Productive General Practice Quick Start (PGPQS) Programme in England.

PGPQS is an on-site, hands-on, short term support package for general practice that forms part of a local time for care programme. It aims to help practices release time for care, build improvement capability and improve collaboration with other practices.

The programme offers hands on support in-practice, from an experienced improvement facilitator. Support is usually given over an eight-week period and includes group sessions with other local practice teams to share improvements and ideas.

4 Deliver Partners have been appointed to service the programme nationally.

Title: Northern Access Works for the North London Heat and Power Project (NLHPP) - AWARD
Description:
North London Waste Authority (the Authority) is seeking a contractor to carry out works to construct a northern access to the Edmonton EcoPark.
      
      North London Waste Authority is a statutory authority whose principal responsibility is the disposal of waste collected by the seven north London boroughs of Barnet, Camden, Enfield, Hackney, Haringey, Islington and Waltham Forest. The Authority predominantly manages its waste arisings through its waste management contract with LondonEnergy Limited (LEL), a private company which is wholly owned by the Authority.  LEL operates an existing Energy from Waste facility at the Edmonton EcoPark which is due to be replaced by the Authority's North London Heat and Power Project (NLHPP). 
      
      Under the NLHPP, the Authority will develop a new Energy Recovery Facility at the Edmonton EcoPark pursuant to a Development Consent Order granted to the Authority on 24 February 2017.  The construction of a northern access to the Edmonton EcoPark is part of the preparatory works for the NLHPP.
      
      The northern access works will provide access to the Edmonton EcoPark from the north via Deephams Farm Road, off Ardra Road. 
      
      Further details of the required works are set out in the Memorandum of Information, forming part of the procurement documents.

Title: Boundary Layer Wind Tunnel (BLWT)
Description:
The University of Southampton is constructing new facilities, and part of this development effort is the update of experimental facilities. 
This Invitation to Tender addresses one of the requirements, namely a new Boundary Layer Wind Tunnel (BLWT) designed as a flexible test platform for novel aerodynamics and fluid mechanics research work and experimental technique. 
The wind tunnel will be installed in a newly constructed building at the University of Southampton's campus. The new building is known as Building 185.
This procurement aims to identify a Contractor to design, manufacture, deliver, install, test and commission the BLWT in accordance with the requirements and performance criteria detailed within the Invitation to Tender document set.
Additional Text:
The University is utilising an electronic tendering tool (In-Tend: https://in­tendhost.co.uk/ universityofsouthampton) to manage this procurement and to communicate with participating organisations. 
All documentation in relation to this tender can be downloaded from In­Tend. 
Participating organisations are advised that there will be no hard copy documents issued to organisations and all communications with the University including the submission of Invitation to Tender responses will be conducted via In-Tend. 
Regular monitoring of In-Tend is the responsibility of the participating organisation. 
If you are not already registered as a supplier with the University of Southampton, you will need to register in In-Tend in order to access the Invitation to Tender documentation. 
Once you have logged in: click on 'Tenders'; locate the relevant project; and click 'View Details'. Once you are in the project screen. you will be able to register your company against the project and access all documentation by clicking 'Express Interest'. 
Further instructions for the submission of Invitation to Tender responses are below. 
To submit your return, please follow the instructions below: 
1.	Login
2.	Click 'Tenders'
3.	Locate the relevant project
4.	View Details
5.	Click on the tab relating to the relevant project stage (e.g. 'Invitation to Tender Stage')
6.	Click on the 'Attach Documents' button and upload your return.
7.	Check ALL your response documents are uploaded and displayed in the "My Tender Return" panel. The system will only permit your organisation to make one return.
8.	Click the red "Submit Return" button.
Please note that to preserve the integrity of the soft market testing exercise, all queries must made be via the correspondence function within In-Tend.

Title: Provision of technical support services to perform independent confirmatory safety analysis
Description:
ONR is seeking to engage one of the Technical Support Contractors (TSC) appointed on Lot 1 of its Technical Support Framework.  
The TSC is required to develop a thermal hydraulic system code computer model of the UK HPR1000.  
1)	A pragmatic approach to its development should be taken to ensure the model can be applied to a selection of fault transients without expending unnecessary effort developing redundant capabilities that are not required. 
2)	The computer model should utilise a point kinetic approach for the reactor physics for the initial work scope.  However, the model should be developed with a view to coupling with the more sophisticated reactor physics model in the final phase.
3)	The computer model should include a basic consideration of containment response.  A more detailed containment model is not envisaged at this time but there is value in providing the capability and flexibility to develop and couple such a modelling if containment behaviour emerges as an area of regulatory interest.
Develop a Core Physics computer model of the UK HPR1000.  
1)	The TSC will use geometric and isotopic data to derive a set of neutron cross sections for each proposed fuel assembly type as a function of irradiation and other suitable dependencies. Given the proposed fuel loading pattern, this will be used to determine the nominal power distribution for full-power conditions. The nuclear data derived will need to take account of the spectral history of each fuel assembly in the equilibrium core to determine appropriate nuclear data. 
2)	The TSC will use the nuclear data produced in 1) to develop a 3D, transient core model suitable for use as part of a wider model for the purposes of fault transient analysis.  The adequacy of the predicted steady state performance will be confirmed by comparison against core power-distribution data supplied.
Attachments: Form of Agreement.docx Call Off Contract - GRS.docx Work Order Specification.docx Warrant No ONR396.docx

Title: Provision of Guardianship (Missing Persons) Surety Bonds
Description:
The Office of the Public Guardian (OPG) is an executive agency of the Ministry of Justice (MoJ) that supports the Public Guardian in discharging his duties. 

The OPG has put in place a contract for the provision of surety bonds, also called security bonds, to cover the performance of guardians of missing persons. 

The aim of the contract is to appoint an insurance broker who will be responsible and accountable for the administration and management of the provision of surety bonds. The broker will be responsible for the procurement exercise to select suitable insurer/ insurers for the provision of surety bonds. 

The Guardianship (Missing Persons) Act 2017 (the Act) was passed to assist families and others to look after the property and financial affairs of a person who is missing. The Act, which comes into force in July 2019, empowers the High Court to appoint a guardian to take control of the property or financial affairs of a missing person. Guardians will be required to act in the best interests of the missing person and to ensure they are carrying out their duties accordingly. 

The High Court will make an order appointing a guardian, which will specify whether a surety bond is required. The court will decide on the value of the surety. The surety bond is a guarantee to pay any financial losses arising from the guardian's improper performance or failure to exercise their functions. 

Guardians will be supervised by the Office of the Public Guardian. The role of the Public Guardian will be similar to his role in the registration and supervision of deputies appointed in respect of persons lacking mental capacity under the Mental Capacity Act 2005.
Contact Address 1: Ministry of Justice, 1st Floor, 5 Wellington Place
Additional Text:
The contract will be a services concession contract. The duration is expected to be two years with the option to extend for two periods of one year (2 + 1 + 1) with an expected start date of June 2019. 

The Contracting Authority intends to use an eTendering system in this procurement exercise and reserves the right to use a reverse auction.

Title: West of England Residual Municipal Waste Treatment Solutions
Description:
The West of England Waste Partnership, consisting of Bath & North East Somerset, Bristol City, North Somerset, and South Gloucestershire Councils, are seeking to procure arrangements for the treatment of their residual municipal solid waste. 

The main requirement is for the acceptance of waste for treatment from 1 April 2020 to 31 March 2030, with the option to extend by one or more periods to 31 March 2040. The awarded contract(s) will allow for the acceptance of some tonnages from 2019 pending available capacity of the successful contractor(s). 

The requirement is split into 2 lots 
Lot 1 -Residual Municipal Waste. Initial tonnages from April 2020 onwards are expected to be up to around 175k tonnes per year. Bidders must have a minimum annual capacity of at least 10,000 tonnes.  At least 90% of waste by tonnage must be diverted away from landfill
Lot 2- Bulky Waste. Initial tonnages from April 2020 onwards are expected to be in the region of 40k-50k tonnes per year. Bidders must have a minimum annual capacity of at least 2,000 tonnes. At least 80% of waste by tonnage must be diverted away from landfill
Bidders will be able to bid for some or all tonnages in either or both Lots. The Councils may award 1 or more contracts covering some or all tonnages available. 
Please see published documents for full requirements and details which can be accessed at https://www.supplyingthesouthwest.org.uk/

Title: ESC19105 - Innovator Support Platform
Description:
Innovator Support Platform (ISP)
Ensuring UK innovators capitalise on the opportunities presented by the energy system transformation is an essential strand of the ESC's mission. SMEs in particular, face a range of systemic challenges and barriers to get new energy-related products and services to market and ready for wide-scale adoption by customers.  At the same time SMEs must contend with the start-up, growth and scale-up challenges many new businesses struggle with, regardless of sector.  
Our response for supporting innovative SME's is to offer a combined solution.   We offer help to refine propositions and open routes to market through applying ESC assets and capabilities to navigate the energy transformation and systemic barriers to market entry.  In parallel, we combine this offering with tailored business growth assistance through access to a broad network of market, technology, and business domain experts, existing incubators, accelerators and external support initiatives. 
This gives rise to the ISP vision, that aligns with the ESC's 5-year Delivery Plan:  "To establish the UK's leading 'virtual' energy incubator, supporting innovators to open routes to market whilst helping them to tackle business growth challenges"
We are delivering this vision through a 3-tier platform that can offer SME's a journey through Universal support, Incubation and Acceleration that suits their needs and stage of business:
1.	Universal Support - standardised offerings accessible by all Innovators (not just SMEs), including sign-posting to ESC partner relationships and network 
2.	Incubation - tailored support for selected SMEs utilising ESC capabilities and delivery partner offerings, particularly for those at an early-stage of business growth 
3.	Acceleration - scale-up support for selected potential high-impact SMEs who can benefit from access to ESC capabilities, its partners, and links to investors, particularly for those at a later-stage of business scale-up
This Framework is primarily seeking services for SMEs at Tier 2 Incubation stage and Tier 3 Acceleration stage.

Title: GEP Academies - Tender for Cleaning Services
Description:
The successful Supplier will be required to provide cleaning services for GEP Academies (the Client) at the following locations:

- Fullbrook School,

- Kings College,

- Sandfield Primary School,

- Boxgrove Primary School.

The Guildford Education Partnership (GEP Academies) was formed in September 2013 from the Multi Academy Trust set up by George Abbot School and Boxgrove Primary School. On 1.9.2014, both Kings College, Guildford and Sandfield Primary School joined GEP with Fullbrook School. Guildford Grove and Loseley Fields Primary School became a member of the Guildford Education Partnership on 1.11.2016.

The group would be looking at harmonising the cleaning contract across all of the member schools. Four schools will be in the initial contract which will take us to co terminus for all 7 schools. The number of schools within the groups is looking to grow significantly through the life of the contract.

The tender project is seeking to appoint a Supplier whose initiative and innovation will be welcomed for the provision of service within the 2 secondary schools and two primary schools.

The contract being tendered is for four years in duration from 1.8.2019 to 31.7.2023.

The academic year is based on a calendar of 195 days. Five days are to be used for staff professional development which means that the schools will be open to receive students for the legal minimum of 190 days. Periodic cleaning is to be carried out during the holiday periods.

The contract offered covers the scope for the provision of all cleaning services within the 4 schools.

Whilst the client prioritises value for money as a key objective of the competitive tender process, the Client is not obliged to accept the lowest price.

The client believes that success should be celebrated and that pupils should enjoy their time at school; if lessons are stimulating and challenging then students will love learning. Much time therefore, is spent reviewing and planning schemes of work to ensure that they are differentiated to meet the needs of all students. As a result, the client is very enthusiastic regarding work experience and apprenticeship proposals and would welcome the input of the successful supplier.

As a group who are continually seeking ways to improve and develop the ethos and environment for students and staff, to give them the facilities they deserve and need to meet the challenges of the 21st Century, any consideration regarding inward capital investment as part of the Supplier's tender submission would be welcomed. The client would wish for the Supplier to look at making this investment for new equipment.

Please be advised that this contract will be let on a 4-year basis.

Further information is provided in the SQ Documentation.
Contact Address 2: George Abbot School, Woodruff Avenue, Burpham
Additional Text:
Interest in the selection process should be expressed via email only to pqq@litmuspartnership.co.uk clearly stating within this email which contract / notice you are referring to. Please also provide, as a minimum, a contact name, full company postal address and telephone number.

The Selection Questionnaire and associated documents can be obtained at: http://www.litmuspartnership.co.uk/project/gep_academies

The closing date for receipt of the Selection Questionnaire is 25.3.2019 (12:00). Suppliers are required to ensure that documents are obtained and returned to The Litmus Partnership Limited, by email to pqq@litmuspartnership.co.uk by the above closing date and time.

Documents in respect of economic / financial standing (where indicated in the Selection Questionnaire) shall be returned to The Litmus Partnership Limited, by email to pqq@litmuspartnership.co.uk by the above closing date and time.

It will be the Supplier's responsibility to obtain any necessary documents in order to submit a response by the closing date and time.

The contracting authority reserves the right not to award any or part of the contract which is the subject of this Contract Notice and reserves the right to terminate the procurement process at any time.

The contracting authority will not be liable for any costs incurred by those expressing an interest in tendering for this contract opportunity.

The contracting authority will consider variant bids, evaluating them (so far as the variant or the evaluation of the variant is in the opinion of the contracting authority practicable) on the same basis as a conforming bid, but shall not be obliged to accept any such bid in preference to a conforming bid even if the variant bid scores more highly. No variant will be considered unless the bidder simultaneously submits a conforming bid.

Title: Supply of a Physical Properties Measurement System (PPMS)
Description:
UKAEA wishes to procure a Physical Property Measurement System (PPMS) offering a wide range of magnetic, thermal and electrical measurements. It has the following minimum requirements:

- "cryogen free", i.e. operated with a cryocooler;
- Sample environment controls including fields up to ±14 tesla;
- variable temperature insert (VTI) with a calibrated Cernox resistive temperature sensor or direct equivalent, provided with a calibration from 1.4 K to room temperature
- Measurement temperature range at least between 2 and 300 K
- Time to sweep to 90% of full field less than 10 min, with a thermal load on the insert
 - Field homogeneity ±0.01% over 3 cm on axis
- Capable of performing the following measurements:
	o	Heat capacity
	o	DC magnetic moment (magnetometry)
	o	AC susceptibility
	o	DC and AC electrical properties
- A sample rotator to perform a measurement with the field at different angles

Title: 3173_19A HIV Self-Sampling Service (Public Health England)
Description:
Public Health England (PHE) is seeking to establish a national framework agreement with a single provider to provide an online HIV self-sampling and results management service for most at risk populations. The aim of this service is to provide a cost effective and clinically robust remote HIV Self-Sampling Service for sexually active individuals aged 16 years and over. Emphasis will be placed on increasing testing for HIV amongst most at risk groups including MSM and black African populations. The service will be paid for by the customer and will be free to the service user. The framework will be primarily for use by PHE and all English local authorities with Public Health responsibilities (170 in England). Its use will not be mandatory.
The Framework is primarily intended to be accessed by Public Health England and English local authorities; however it will be open for use by any public body/contracting authority being either:

a) Public Health England;
c) any local authority in England; or
b) the NHS Commissioning Board;
d) any clinical commissioning group, NHS Trust or NHS Foundation Trust in England

The provider will design, host, manage and maintain a secure and accessible user-friendly interface that provides access to free remote sampling services, the supply of self-sampling kits for capillary or finger-tip blood sampling, testing of samples, appropriate results management and onward referral for treatment and care following diagnosis.

The framework agreement has the option to extend for up to a further 18 months, taking the maximum period available to 4 years. The total estimated value stated includes the option period.

To tender: (a) Go to www.eastmidstenders.org, (b) Register (c) Search for tender opportunity 3173_19A d) Express an interest (e) Download the tender from the website.

Please note:  the closing date for submission of tenders is 12:00 midday, 28/05/2019

Title: Unity Schools Trust - Tender for Catering Services
Description:
Unity Schools Trust is a geographically based Multi-Academy Trust (MAT), formed in September 2015. All academies in the MAT are governed by 1 trust, with clear lines of delegation to local governing bodies in each academy. We have 2 schools in our trust currently, namely, The Magna Carta School in Staines and Bishop David Brown School in Woking.

The tender project is seeking to appoint a supplier whose initiative and innovation will be welcomed for the provision of service within the existing facilities for the 1 250 students and 139 teaching and support staff at The Magna Carta School, and 615 students and 64 teaching and support staff at Bishop David Brown School, with a focus on exciting new food concepts to satisfy a wide range of pupil tastes and dietary requirements. The Trust would wish the successful supplier to review the current range of services offered and make recommendations accordingly.

The contract being tendered is for 3 years in duration from 2019 to 2022 and will operate as a guaranteed performance contract, with the successful supplier offering the trust a guaranteed return/cost per annum for the provision of catering services. Sovereignty of the cash tariff is to remain with the Unity Schools Trust for the duration of this contract.

The academic year is based on a calendar of 195 days. 5 days are to be used for staff professional development which means that the schools will be open to receive students for the legal minimum of 190 days.

The contract offered covers the scope for the provision of all catering services within the schools, which currently includes morning break, lunch, all hospitality and free issue requirements with the potential of offering breakfast. Free School Meals will be charged based on consumption and at net food cost.

Whilst the Trust prioritises value for money as a key objective of the competitive tender process, the governing body is not obliged to accept the lowest price.

The Unity Schools Trust expects the successful supplier to enable the continued development of catering through the provision of an innovative, healthy food service, with fresh, seasonal, locally sourced ingredients being prepared on-site. The Trust expects the successful supplier to evidence, through their bid, how they shall support and complement its values.

The Trust believes that success should be celebrated and that students should enjoy their time at school; if lessons are stimulating and challenging then students will love learning. Much time therefore, is spent reviewing and planning schemes of work to ensure that they are differentiated to meet the needs of all students.

Further information is provided in the SQ Document.
Additional Text:

Title: Girls' Learning Trust - Tender for Catering Services
Description:
The successful supplier will be required to provide catering services for the Girls' Learning Trust at the following schools:

- Nonsuch High School for girls,

- Wallington High School for girls,

- Carshalton High School for girls.

The Girls' Learning Trust (GLT) was formed on 1.9.2015 and was originally called the Nonsuch and Wallington Education Trust (NWET). At first there were 2 schools in the Trust; Nonsuch High School for Girls and Wallington High School for girls. In April 2018, Carshalton High School for girls joined the Trust. All 3 schools are high performing, successful schools located in the London Borough of Sutton and are within easy reach of each other.

With around 4 000 students, 400 staff and a highly effective operating model, GLT gives member schools the financial and operational strength to drive school improvement and provides increased opportunities for students and staff across the Trust.

The tender project is seeking to appoint a supplier whose initiative and innovation will be welcomed for the provision of service within the existing facilities for the students and teaching/support staff at each Trust school. The client requires a focus on exciting new food concepts to satisfy a wide range of pupil tastes and dietary requirements. The client would wish the successful supplier to review the current range of services offered and make recommendations accordingly.

The contract being tendered is for 3 years in duration from 1.8.2019 to 31.7.2022 with the option to extend this contract by a further 2 years, in agreement with the client. The contract will operate as a guaranteed performance contract, with the successful supplier offering the Client a guaranteed return/cost per annum for the provision of catering services. Sovereignty of the cash tariff is to remain with the client for the duration of this contract.

The academic year is based on a calendar of 195 days. 5 days are to be used for staff professional development which means that school will be open to receive students for the legal minimum of 190 days.

The contract offered covers the scope for the provision of all school catering services, which currently includes morning break, lunch, all hospitality and free issue requirements. Free school meals will be charged based on uptake and at a margin, where hospitality will be provided at net food cost.

Whilst the Client prioritises value for money as a key objective of the competitive tender process, the client is not obliged to accept the lowest price.

The client expects the successful supplier to enable the continued development of catering through the provision of an innovative, healthy food services, with fresh, seasonal, locally sourced ingredients being prepared on-site. The client expects the successful supplier to evidence, through their bid, how they shall support and complement its values and support the principles of every child matters.

Further information is provided in the SQ Documentation.
Contact Address 2: Nonsuch High School for Girls, Ewell Road

Title: Convent of Jesus and Mary Language College - Tender for Catering Services
Description:
The successful supplier will be required to provide catering services at Convent of Jesus and Mary Language College at Crownhill Road, Willesden, London, NW10 4EP.

With approximately 950 pupils, Convent of Jesus and Mary Language College is a Catholic secondary school for girls and has enjoyed over 10 years as a specialist Language College. It was one of the first schools to achieve specialist status in this area and received funding directly from the government to promote languages and the international dimension both within the school and in the local community. The school also has an active sixth form for 180 places.

Convent of Jesus and Mary Language College is part of the diocese of Westminster Academy Trust. The last OFSTED inspection was judged as "good".

Basis of contract:

The client wishes to participate in a tender process with the intention of appointing a supplier to deliver full catering services. The contract is estimated to commence in September 2019 and will be for an initial period of 3 years plus an option to extend up to a maximum of 5 years.

In order to deliver best value, the contract will be awarded on a "cost-plus" with fixed guaranteed lines on food and labour costs.

The revenue is estimated to be 550 000 (over 3 years).

Objectives:

The appointed supplier will have significant experience of delivering quality catering services within secondary school premises and should have suitable experience and expertise of successfully increasing pupil meal uptake and lunchtime sales growth. With the experience of successfully managing the TUPE process, the supplier should ideally have a strong operational base in London, together with an ambition and compelling attitude towards forging a congenial partnership with the school's leadership team that stimulates a joint determination to achieve success.

Ultimately it is important that the supplier can demonstrate integrity with an ability to manage an efficient catering service through the application of best practice and innovation and as a result will be expected to deliver sustainable quality and "best value" to the school.
Contact Address 1: Convent of Jesus and Mary Language College

Description:
Hampshire County Council invites applications from suitably experienced organisations who wish to be considered for selection to tender for Supporting Hampshire Young Carers.

The Service Provider will carry out assessments, where required, and provide access to support, tailored information and advice and targeted group activities for young carers as appropriate. These activities may be provided by the Service Provider(s) or referred and signposted on to other organisations to deliver.
      
      The Contract will commence on 1st July 2019 and will be for a period of two years with the option to extend for a further two years.
      
      Interested parties should register their interest in the project via the In-Tend website https://in-tendhost.co.uk/hampshire, and complete and submit the tender return document together with any supporting information requested by 14.00 hrs on Wednesday 24th April 2019.

Title: Hampshire Carers Support & Dementia Advisors Service - AWARD
Description:
Hampshire County Council invite suitably experienced providers to tender for the provision of services supporting carers and people living with dementia who live within the geographic jurisdiction of Hampshire County Council. 
      
      There will be four (4) contract lots of service provision. Three (3) of these contract lots will focus on the provision to carers and people living with dementia of a range of information, advice and support. The fourth lot ("Lot 4") will have a specific focus on working with carers to produce emergency plans for activation at such times when the carer is unable to undertake their caring role. 
      
      The breakdown of lots will be as follows, together with the annual contract value for each lot: 
      Lot 1: North Hampshire (incorporating the districts and boroughs of Basingstoke and Dene, Hart and Rushmoor). Annual contract value: £238,562 per annum.
      Lot 2: West Hampshire (incorporating the districts and boroughs of: Winchester, Test Valley, Eastleigh and the New Forest). Annual contract value: £380,256 per annum.
      Lot 3: East Hampshire (incorporating the Boroughs and Districts of East Hampshire, Havant, Fareham and Gosport). Annual contract value: £307,541 per annum.
      Lot 4: (Carers Emergency Planning Service, covering the geographic jurisdiction of Hampshire County Council). Annual contract value: £189,641 per annum. 
      The Council may exercise an option to purchase additional related services, including, but not limited to, the provision of services providing information, advice and support to carers in the context of hospital discharge up to the value of £300k and also for increased training delivery up to the value of £50k in any one year respectively.
      
      For all four lots, the service commencement date is 1st April 2019. 
      For each of the four lots the initial contract term is for a period of 3 years, with the option in each case, at the discretion of Hampshire County Council, to extend for a period or periods not exceeding two years.
      
      Interested parties should register their interest in AS12531 Hampshire Carers Support & Dementia Advisors Service via the In-Tend website https://in-tendhost.co.uk/hampshire from Friday 26th October 2018 and must complete and submit the tender return documents together with any additional supporting information requested by 14.00 hrs / 2p.m. on Monday 3rd December 2018.

Title: RBKC Youth Services Framework
Description:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea has commissioned a "Pseudo" Open Framework Agreement consisting of multiple suitably qualified providers under which it can Call-off (via mini-competition) a range of youth related service for young people aged 11 - 19 (up to 25 for young people with special educational needs or disabilities, SEND) in the borough.

The "Pseudo" Open Framework Agreement has been commissioned under the Light Touch Regime (implemented through regulations 74-77 of the Public Contract Regulations 2015). This Framework Agreement differs from those let under the non-light touch regime in that the Council may exercise its flexibility to periodically 'open' the framework for providers to submit applications to join, particularly if it needs to increase capacity or to respond to emerging needs. If the Council decides to open up the "Pseudo" Open Framework Agreement for applications, it will do so on the same terms and conditions and on the same criteria.

Title: Intermediate Nursing Care Provision
Description:
The contract is awarded under the Negotiation Procedure without prior publication in line with requirements as competition was absent for technical reasons (Regulation 32 (2) (b)(ii). The Council believes that the reasons for the use of this procedure have been met due to the paucity of registered nursing homes in borough, and indeed nationally.
Currently there are only 2 nursing homes registered by the Care Quality Commission in borough that is, this one and another, which is presently not in position to deliver this provision. The contract will deliver Intermediate specialist nursing care services. Access to and the efficacy of, Intermediate nursing care provision is reliant on community health professionals, within a multi-disciplinary team. The criteria for which is residence and registration with an in-borough GP, which would preclude use of out of borough provision as well as, lead to the loss of rehabilitative input which is the crucial element of this service

Title: Police & Fire Medical Appeal Board Framework
Description: The Secretary of State for the Home Department ("the Home Office") has overall responsibility for policing in England and Wales and for the fire service in England only. Policing in Scotland and the fire service in both Wales and Scotland are devolved powers. However, the requirements under the contract being tendered relate to both policing and fire in England, Scotland and Wales. The Home Office requires a provider to manage boards of medical referees who will conduct medical appeals under the appropriate police & fire pension regulations in England, Wales and Scotland. The required services comprise the provision of regional Medical Appeal Boards for the police and fire services in England, Wales and Scotland, in accordance with relevant pension and injury benefit regulations. SCOPE The scope of the Framework Agreement includes the following: *Administering Police and Fire Medical Appeal Boards; *Recruitment and training of members with appropriate expertise. *Monitoring and reporting of key performance indicators. *Producing annual and quarterly reports submitted formally to the Home Office. *Access to legal advice both before and after the hearings, whether from providers own legally qualified staff or through external legal advisers' and 'post decision case-work. *Providing stakeholders, such as pension authorities, selected medical practitioners, fire trades unions and the Police Federation with at least one day of training per year in relation to Medical Appeal Boards. Training will be based on stakeholder needs and feedback from board members and is distinct from training provided by parent organisations. *To ensure independence of the appeal board process.
Additional Text: Additional information and joining instruction can be found within the attachment: "PAFMAB instructions"

Title: TENDER FOR THE SUPPLY OF TRAVEL MANAGEMENT SERVICES
Description:
The LTE Group is faced with circumstances of urgency which render impracticable the time limit laid down in relation to an open procedure by Regulation 27(5) of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015, and which would ordinarily apply to such a procedure. Therefore LTE Group need to publish this Tender opportunity under the Accelerated Open Procedure for The Supply of Travel Management Services 2019.

The LTE Group intends to arrange a Contract Agreement with an appropriate supplier for The Supply of Public Sector Travel & Venue Solutions, including but not limited to: 

Public Sector Travel Management Services:

TRAVEL MANAGEMENT SCOPE
ITEM 1	Online Booking and System Requirements
ITEM 2	Offline Booking and Offline Services
ITEM 3	Airline Bookings - Online & Offline
ITEM 4	Rail Booking - Online & Offline
ITEM 5	Accommodation Booking - Online & Offline
ITEM 6	Group Bookings - Offline Only
ITEM 7	Conference and Events Management
ITEM 8	Management, Booking & Payment Of Guest Speakers 
ITEM 9	Taxi & Private Hire Service (Hackney Cabs & PHV's Or Mini Cabs)
ITEM 10 Lease Vehicles or Hire Vehicles (Including Mini Buses)

The successful supplier securing a position on this Contract Agreement will be able to provide services from their own banks of provision or from third party service providers but in all instances the orders will be placed with, invoiced by, and managed by, the Awarded Contract Holder named on the LTE Group Contract or their nominated distributor with the express permission of LTE Group. The Contract Agreement will require a combination of day to day servicing with low value orders as well as small, medium and high value travel demand and project work. 

The LTE Group anticipates that the Contract Agreement will be with fit for purpose Service providers who will offer considerable "Added Value" benefits through a strategic alliance with all operating divisions of the LTE Group. All operating divisions of the LTE Group have a demanding infrastructure/environment and the extensive Travel Management requirement will be utilised for a variety of environments, including but not limited to Further and Higher Education, Training, Office, Hospitality, Conferencing, Events,  The Justice Sector i.e. Prisons, Custodial Establishments and Other miscellaneous settings.
Additional Text:
Tender submissions must be returned via the Proactis Contract Tendering Portal. If you have any issues in using the Proactis Tendering Portal please Telephone Proactis 0330 0050352.

Where Suppliers have any queries about the Tender documentation which may have a bearing on the offer to be made, these should be via the Proactis Tender Portal. Where any such enquiry has been made, the LTE Group will anonymise and circulate to all Suppliers a copy of the enquiry and the written reply, anonymity will be preserved, unless it is deemed they are of a strictly confidential nature. No Email or Telephone Clarifications will be allowed. 

Tender submissions must reach the LTE Group via the Proactis Tendering Portal by 12.00 noon 15th April 2019. Late Tender bids will not be considered.

Title: TENDER FOR THE PROVISION OF ENVIRONMENTAL BRANDING SERVICES FOR LTE GROUP
Description:
The purpose of this Tender Arrangement is to secure an arrangement with the LTE Group for Environmental Branding Services, with an experienced Provider to deliver the best possible arrangement in conjunction with exceptional service provision and demonstrable value for the LTE Group.

The Provider will be instrumental in delivering a cost-effective, reliable and flexible large format printing and installation provision with national reach and the capability to deliver quality products and service at pace to achieve LTE Group's stakeholder objectives.

The successful Provider will work reliably, flexibly and in collaboration with LTE Group and its organisations to produce the required signage orders precisely, as specified, within the pre-stipulated timeframes using quality, durable materials as agreed, and with all printing undertaken to an accurate and high-quality standard.
With the successive growth of the organisational structure that is LTE Group, the previous years have seen a steadily increasing demand for a dedicated professional, environmental branding and signage provider to support our in-house team and businesses.

Whilst our group's in-house marketing teams provide the itemised artwork for the development of projects and campaigns, briefs and budgets, the environmental branding provider will have the technical expertise, capability, and organisational integrity to realise the vision to maximise the return on investment.

Below are a few examples of how we will utilise the supplier to fulfil signage orders on an ongoing basis:

•	Graduation event

•	Open Day/Evening events

•	Campus branding

•	External stands for events

•	Awards Dinners

•	Conferences

•	External meetings

•	Staff and student events

Aplication to this tender and all communication regarding this tender will be managed via the ProContract procurement portal.

Title: Specialist Domestic Abuse
Description:
The London Borough of Sutton require the provision and coordination of Specialist Domestic Abuse Services.

We seek to develop and commission a systems-wide response to Domestic Abuse which: 

•	Demonstrates and delivers a joined up approach of commissioned specialist services, where the pathways are clear and users of the service are referred into and between services based on their level of need. 
•	Reduces levels of dependency on statutory services by victims and increases their levels of independence. 
•	Reduces the levels of risk to victims, children and families. 
•	Effects real change in the incidence of domestic abuse by perpetrators. 
•	Supports children, families, victims and perpetrators to achieve long term sustainable, positive changes which bring about improved outcomes. 

Services will provide targeted support to victims, perpetrators, of domestic abuse and children affected by DA. Services will be delivered across Sutton and will encompass interventions that aim to address the complex problems associated with domestic abuse.

Title: DFID 8484 Invest Salone Contract Award
Description:
Invest Salone will deliver two high level objectives:
a) Investment climate reform. Invest Salone will reduce the risk of doing business, levelling the playing field for all firms, including high quality international investors. The programme will identify government institutions with the political will and capacity to
tackle the barriers holding back firms, and support them to reform and simplify their processes. Invest Salone will equip firms with the knowledge and tools to follow these processes effectively and hold institutions to account where needed. Invest Salone will prioritise ensuring the rules change on the ground, not just on the books.
b) Market development. Invest Salone will mobilise the capabilities and resources of the private sector to achieve development outcomes. The programme will apply market systems development principles, using the latest evidence on what does and does not
work and building on experience using the approach in thin markets. Invest Salone will use a spectrum of tools to develop markets, underpinned by strict adherence to DFID's Policy on Subsidy to the Private Sector.

Title: Project Saturn
Description:
UK Asset Resolution Ltd (UKAR) is nearing completion of its objective of returning the UK taxpayers' investment in NRAM Ltd (NRAM) and Bradford and Bingley plc (B&B) to the private sector. One option is to sell the NRAM and B&B legal entities, leaving UKAR in public ownership.

UKAR is therefore seeking to establish a single supplier contract to outsource all aspects of the running of its remaining business, with the exception of board and company secretarial functions.

UKAR will be responsible for meeting contractual obligations to the buyer of B&B and NRAM, a range of liabilities relating to previous asset sales, sponsoring the legacy defined benefit pension schemes and administering other non-loan assets and liabilities.

The scope of the contract requires the provision of claims management services and the outsourcing of business administration activities required to run the business, such as management reporting, stakeholder management and other miscellaneous activities (such as, potentially, residual pension management responsibilities). It also involves the planning and management of the transition to the new arrangements.

Title: STC1130-Pest Control Services - AWARD
Description:
Provision of Estate-wide planned and responsive pest control services to include a wide range of pests including (but not limited to) mice, rats, crawling insects and flying insects such as clothes moths.  Services shall include treatment, control, eradication and monitoring of pest affected properties, the provision of all traps, bait boxes and the like and follow up visits to ensure successful treatment and removal/replacement of bait, traps, and removal of carcasses, as appropriate. The appointed supplier will also be required to update the Employer's bespoke pest control data management system and provide all reports required.
      
      To include the dedicated services of a pest technician qualified to RSPH or BPCA Diploma Level III Certificate in Pest Control part 2 or equivalent. 
      
      Provision of an emergency call out services 24/7 365/366 days with attendance within 4 hours of notification.
      Companies wishing to tender for this requirement are required to be a member of a recognised trade body such as (but not limited to) the British Pest Control Association (BPCA) or The National Pest Technicians Association (NPTA) or national bodies of equivalent standing.

Title: Processing of Mixed Dry Recyclables - AWARD
Description:
The Authority is seeking contractors to provide waste management services to:
      1. Receive and process the MDR;
      2. Separate and market the recyclable materials; and
      3. Dispose of non-recyclable residue.
      As detailed in the Specification (Schedule 1 of the Invitation to Submit Initial Tenders), the services are divided into 10 lots each with the same anticipated volume of MDR tonnages.
      
      The successful tenderer(s) shall:
      (a) receive such MDR at the proposed MRF as is delivered by the Authority, the Boroughs or their designated contractors; or 
      (b) provide an alternative Delivery Point within the Delivery Area for the receipt, bulking and transport of MDR to their MRF.
      The Delivery Area and the process for the award of lots is two phases in accordance with the location of the Delivery Point are explained in the procurement documents.
      
      At the discretion of the Authority, the successful tenderer or tenderers may be required to provide a collection service from the Oakleigh Road depot of London Borough of Barnet, one of the waste collection authorities amongst the six (6) north London boroughs.
      
      The services are divided into 10 lots with the same anticipated volume of MDR tonnages. Each lot will have an estimated tonnage size of 9.000 to 15,000 tonnes of MDR. The Authority may vary the tonnages in individual lots throughout the contract according to the tonnages of MDR arising. Tonnages of MDR are a contractor risk as the Authority does not guarantee any minimum or maximum tonnages for each lot or for the total lots.
      
      
      
      The Authority reserves the right to award all, some or none of the Lots.
      
      Any contract resulting from the procurement process shall be for an initial term of six years commencing on 16 December 2019 and ending on 15 December 2025 (with an option for both parties to agree to extend the term on up to four occasions not exceeding a maximum period of four years in total as detailed in the contract), subject to earlier termination in accordance with the terms of the contract.
      
      Details of the key requirements of the contract are set out in the Specification included at Schedule 1 of the ISIT and the other procurement documents available at in-tendhost.co.uk/nlwa.

Title: IT Training Programme Framework
Description:
EMSCU is acting on behalf of the Contracting Authority to undertake a compliant EU tender exercise using the light touch regime under Schedule 3 (Open Procedure) of the Public Contract Regulations (2015) to establish a national framework agreement for IT Training Programme. The Framework Consists of three Lots:
Lot 1 Technical Courses
Lot 2 Non Technical Courses
Lot 3 Bespoke / Custom Courses. Bidders that have been awarded either Lots 1 or 2 will also be awarded Lot 3 if they have the ability to provide (Not Scored)

Lot 1 Technical
This Lot will cover the provision of "off the shelf" solutions and specialist education and training for IT professionals of a technical nature. Typical activities required under this Lot include, but are not restricted to the attached course list.
Technical training could include blended learning offerings, e.g. e-learning, remote access, classroom, on site.

Lot 2 Non-Technical
This Lot will cover the provision of "off the shelf" solutions and specialist education and training for IT professionals of a non-technical nature which includes business and soft skills. Typical activities required under this Lot include, but are not restricted to the attached course list.
Non-technical training could include blended learning offerings, e.g. e-learning, remote access, classroom, on site.

Lot 3 Custom / Bespoke
**Please Note: Can only be awarded to a Supplier that has been awarded at least one lot (1 or 2).Users of Lot 3 will only be able to conduct Mini Competition (No Direct Award)**
This Lot will cover the provision of bespoke/custom solutions and specialist education and training for IT professionals. This is expected to be for softer skills. However, could include technical and non-technical business skills. Typical topic areas required under this Lot include, but are not restricted to:
• Commercial awareness
• Emotional Intelligence
• Finance for non-financial managers
• IT Market trends
• Leadership Skills
• Management Skills
• Managing conflict
• Stakeholder relationships
• Negotiating and influencing
• Talent development
Bespoke/custom could include blended learning offerings, e.g. e-learning, remote access, classroom, on site.
Contact Address 1: c/o East Midlands Strategic Commercial Unit (EMSCU), Nottinghamshire Police, Force Headquarters, Sherwood Lodge, Arnold

Title: CON19004 - Principal Contractor for the Construction of the Harwell Training Centre
Description:
The final date and time for the submission of bids is Tuesday 2nd April 2019 at 14:00 GMT.

DO NOT apply directly to the buyer.

All tender information MUST be submitted through the CCS eSourcing Portal.

Brief Description of Requirement
UK Research and Innovation - MEdical Research Council have a requirement to procure a Principal Contractor for the Contstruction of the Harwell Training Centre. 

Building 524 at the Harwell campus will be redeveloped to provide a new training centre. The project comprises the refurbishment of the existing building and infilling of the existing courtyard to provide additional floor space. Work to the existing building includes significant façade upgrades and internal MEP upgrades.
The proposed redevelopment will deliver training laboratories, preparation spaces, an animal holding space, teaching spaces, breakout spaces, reception & meeting rooms, additional external parking, hard & soft landscaping and other ancillary works. The project includes the supply and install of specialist downdraft benches forming part of the training laboratories.
The existing building to be refurbished has approximately 665m2 of floor space, the new infill building is to be approximately 105m2.

Please ensure you review all attached information to ensure a full understanding of this requirement. All attachments can be found with the RFx attachments tab within the Emptoris System. 

This contract will be awarded based on the evaluation criteria set out in the ITQ document. 

How to Apply

As part of the strategic alliance between UK Shared Business Services Ltd (UK SBS) and Crown Commercial Service (CCS), UK SBS will be using the CCS eSourcing Suite for this procurement.

To register on the CCS eSourcing portal please follow the details contained within the Additional Information section of this notice.

If you are already registered on the CCS eSourcing portal and wish to register your interest in this opportunity please email; expressionofinterest@crowncommercial.gov.uk 

Your email must clearly state: 
•	the name and reference for the procurement you wish to register for; 
•	the name of the registered Bidder; 
•	the name and contact details for the registered individual sending the email.

Please disregard any content in this notice that requests your organisation "to apply directly to the buyer" as this unfortunately a system generated error, that is outside of the Contracting Authorities control.
Attachments: Bidder Training.pdf Bidder - Logging into Emptoris for the first time.pdf CON19004 - Principal Contractor for the Construction of the Harwell Training Centre  - Invitation to Quote Questions.pdf CON19004 - Invitation to Quote - Amended.pdf
Additional Text:
DO NOT APPLY DIRECTLY TO BUYER

All submissions will be assessed in accordance with the Public Contracts Regulations 2015, for procurement values that exceed Regulation 5 (Threshold amounts)

Responses must be received by the date in the tender documentation; responses received outside of the deadline or not sent via the eSourcing portal will not be accepted or considered further for this opportunity.

How to Register on the CCS eSourcing Suite

If you have not yet registered on the eSourcing Suite, this can be done online at https://gpsesourcing.cabinetoffice.gov.uk by following the link 'Register for CCS eSourcing'. 

Please note that, to register, you must have a valid DUNS number (as provided by Dun and Bradstreet) for the organisation which you are registering, who will be entering into a contract if invited to do so. 

Once you have registered on the eSourcing Suite, a registered user can express an interest for a specific procurement. This is done by emailing expressionofinterest@crowncommercial.gov.uk. 

Your email must clearly state: 
•	name and reference for the procurement you wish to register for; 
•	name of the registered Bidder; 
•	name and contact details for the registered individual sending the email.
